name: Dún Bolg

attributes.attribute: located on the Isle of Skye near Isleornsay
portal through which Cúchulainn’s warriors invaded the Otherworld
possesses a magical Cauldron of abundance

sources: Condren, Mary. The Serpent and the Goddess: Women, Religion and Power in Ancient Ireland. San Francisco: Harper & Row, 1989, 66.
Raftery, Brian. Pagan Celtic Ireland: The Enigma of the Irish Iron Age. London: Thames and Hudson, 1994, 71.
Monaghan, Patricia. The Encyclopedia of Celtic Mythology and Folklore. Checkmark Books, 2008.
text: At the legendary site of Dún Bolg, the warriors of Leinster demonstrated their unwillingness to pay the bórama, or Cow-tribute, demanded by the king of Tara. Their ingenious plan, not unlike the trickery of the Trojan Horse, involved hidden warriors bursting out of baskets attached to the backs of the tribute-carrying cows, and successfully battled the king's soldiers. Cúchulainn, on the other hand, found his home in Dún Delgan, which was named after the Fomorian chieftain Delga. The Irish town of Dundalk bears the same name. Also known as the stronghold of warrior woman Scáthach, Dún Scaith was situated at the Isle of Skye near Isleornsay. Its name also referred to a portal to the Otherworld on the Isle of Man that Cúchulainn's army used to capture the Cauldron of abundance.
